data.text:
Punctuality is known as a German key virtue. The most common way to ask for the time in German is actually âWie spÃ¤t ist es?â, which translates to âHow late is it?â. Itâs usually not âWhat is the time?â and itâs definitely never âHow early is it?â.

Instead of simply asking for the time like speakers of most other languages, German-speakers seem to be haunted by the ever-lurking threat of being too late.

So if youâre learning German to converse with German-speakers, weâll make sure youâre always right on time by teaching you all the important time-related German expressions - including common snack times and some fun games.

Why learn how to tell the time in German?

Strike up a conversation

Asking someone for the time is an excellent way to start a conversation. So when you find yourself in a German-speaking environment and you want to test out your German skills, knowing how to tell the time in German will be a major advantage.

Just ask anyone âEntschuldigung, wie spÃ¤t ist es?â and youâll have a perfectly legitimate excuse to strike up your first German conversation - even with a stranger.

Time is an integral part of the language

Once you learn how to tell the time in German, you can better understand some fun German expressions and idioms that are all time-related. When itâs âhigh time to actâ, in German itâs âkurz vor zwÃ¶lfâ - just before 12 oâclock.

Even expressions that are not time-related per se can be time-related in German. Instead of calling out âOh dearâ for example, German-speakers will call out âAch du liebe Zeitâ - âoh, you dear time!â

Time is inevitable

As time never stops, itâs hard to escape it. When youâre trying to become fluent in a language, youâll eventually run into having to tell the time.

If your colleague sets up a meeting, your friends want to meet you for lunch or youâre simply wondering if the grocery store is closing anytime soon - in all aspects of daily life, time is inevitable. So itâs helpful to get a hold of it in the language youâre learning.

What time is it in German?

We've put together a worksheet to help you practice your time telling skills! Once you've completed the worksheet you can then use your mobile phone to scan the QR code for the correct answers. Good luck!

How to tell the time in German

To get started, of course itâs important that you learn how to count in German first. Youâll need the numbers from 1 to 24, as in German a 24-hour-format, elsewhere known as military time, is used.

Once you know these, you can add the German word âUhrâ [uÉÌ¯/] to the respective number, and youâll know how to say the full hour.

How to ask what the time is in German?

The German word for time is âZeitâ [tÍ¡saÉªÌ¯t], which has found its way into the English language as part of the noun âzeitgeistâ, commonly used as the defining mood of a specific time period. It is therefore known by many English-speakers. Interestingly though, there is no German way to ask for the time that actually includes the word âZeitâ.

If you ask âWie ist die Zeit?â, German-speakers would probably understand what youâre asking, but you would not hear a native speaker use that expression. Itâs possible to ask âWie viel Uhr ist es?â, which translates to âHow many oâclock is it?â, but itâs most common to ask how late it is if you want to know the time: âWie spÃ¤t ist es?â [Êi ÊpÉËt Éªst És].

How to say the time of day in German

German time, like all time, is measured in years, months, weeks and days. Each day starts in the morning (âMorgenâ) and ends at night (âNachtâ) and there are a number of times in between that we have listed for you.

But if weâre honest, most of us count their daytimes in mealtimes anyway, right? So we included those as well. A special one in German is âKaffee und Kuchenâ, a time in the afternoon between lunch and dinner, when Germans dedicate a break to coffee and cake!

How to tell exact minutes in German

To tell the exact time in German, you name the hour first, followed by âUhrâ and the exact number of minutes. German uses the numbers from 0-12 for the first twelve hours of the day and continues to count from 13 to 24 oâclock for the second half.

This replaces AM and PM, so 1:07pm for example is 13:07, pronounced as âDreizehn Uhr siebenâ. In Germany and Austria, you use a Doppelpunkt to separate the hours from the minutes (15:07), while in Switzerland, you use a dot instead (15.07).

Other ways to express time in German

In Western Germany, Bavaria, Baden-Wuerttemberg, in Switzerland and in Western Austria, mostly the official version âviertel nach dreiâ (quarter past three) are used, while in Eastern parts of Germany and East Austria, there is a common alternative.

Here, youâll likely hear âviertel vierâ (quarter four) for the same time designation. Similarly they say âdrei viertel zwÃ¶lf.â vs. âviertel vor zwÃ¶lfâ (quarter before twelve). This often leads to misunderstandings even between German-speakers.

In the worst case scenario, if someone wants to meet you at âviertel elfâ and youâre not sure what it means, be prepared to wait for them anytime between 10 and 12 oâclock and you should be on the safe side. If you donât have time for that, refer to this table instead:

Time in German FAQs

How do I say decades in German?

A decade is a âJahrzehntâ in GermanÂ

1990 is âNeunzehnhundertneunzigâ; andÂ

the 90s are âdie Neunziger Jahreâ.

How do I ask âhow longâ in German?

How long in German is âwie lang?â.

How do I tell military time in German?

Military time counts the day in 24 hours, so 1-12 noon are the same as in English, while 1-12 from there on are replaced by 13-24.

Why do Germans use military time?

German-speakers use the system that is also known as military time because there is no equivalent of the English a.m. and p.m. So, to be clear if theyâre referring to daytime or nighttime, they use precise numbers from 0-24.

Games to make learning telling the time in German more fun

Games are the best way to learn anything

We believe that learning something new should always be fun and the easiest way to have some fun is with games. There are countless games for children to learn the time. Pick a fun one from a wide variety of board games and phone games and feel like a kid again.

The Pronouncing Game

Even just trying to pronounce certain times of the day can be fun in German. Whenever you check the time for yourself, make it a game to see if you can say the time in German as well. Have you ever tried to say 15:55h in German? Itâs âfÃ¼nfzehn Uhr fÃ¼nfundfÃ¼nfzigâ!

Time Memory

Another way to learn the time is to make up your own game of Memory. Cut out two sets of square papers. On one of them, youâll write the time in a 24-hour-system (i.e. 7:30, 13:13, 20:15).

On the other set youâll write the matching equivalent spelled out in German (Sieben Uhr DreiÃig, Dreizehn Uhr Dreizehn, Zwanzig Uhr FÃ¼nfzehn). Make sure you draw a little clock with the time on each paper, so you can make sure you found a match. You can read about more fun vocabulary memorization tricks here.

Your time to learn the time

Of course not every German is always punctual, as youâll soon notice when you get to spend some time with a number of them, but generally speaking, being on time is a big deal in German-speaking countries.

Therefore, telling the time in German is an important part of learning the language. Itâs always something oâclock, which gives you constant opportunities to practice. Whatâs the time for you right now? Try saying it in German. Mittagszeit? Dreizehn Uhr DreiunddreiÃig?

Either way, itâs never too late to learn how to tell the time in German - even if itâs kurz vor zwÃ¶lf!
